author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   Abnormal Lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer.   Sometimes, following infection, Lymph nodes remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (about 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection (hard, fixed, increasing progressively in size). These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.   Individuals with history of recurrent upper respiratory, ear, throat dental, and scalp infections tend to have clinically palpable lymph nodes.   So, the probability that the lymph node you have noticed is due to previous infection in the area drained by this lymph node group is high.   Of significance, an increase in nodal size on serial examinations. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size after infection control tend to be more reassuring.   Hope this information is useful.  Keep us updated.  Best regards
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Safaa Mahmoud » Thu Jan 04, 2007 5:41 pm

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,   The swelling you have described that is felt on the Right upper side of the neck behind the ear is probably enlarged Lymph nodes as it occurs in a Lymph node region. Abnormal Lymph node enlargement commonly results from infection / immune response, cancer.   Following infection Lymph nodes become enlarged, painful and tender.   A history of scalp infected lesions, or Ear infection may be present, as this lymph node could be a reactionary to infection in the area drained by this lymph node group.   The other swelling could be another lymph node draining the other side of the scalp and also a reactionary to infection.  After treatment of infection with adequate course of antibiotics, they should regress in size but never to normal size.   Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are significant and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.   It is unusual to get another enlarged lymph node after a course of antibiotic as the antibiotic should clear also the primary infected lesion (e.g. scalp infections like folliculitis), however it is possible with inadequate therapy.  Direct clinical examination is essential to exclude other causes like abscess, lymphoma , etc.   I advise you to follow up with your doctor. Keep us updated.  Best regards.

title: Mobile lump under my chin
content: Hi I'm a 28 yr male, perfectly healthy and I've noticed a smaller than pea size lump under my chin.  It is mobile; it is not soar or anything like that.  Do you have any idea what it is.  It has been there for about a week. thanks

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The submental lymph node is located just below the chin. It drains the lower lip, floor of mouth, teeth, submental salivary gland, tip of tongue, skin of cheek. Common causes of enlargement include mononucleosis syndromes, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, dental pathology such as periodontitis. Sometimes when the submental salivary gland becomes inflammed and swollen it can be confusion with this condition.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal.   Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  You should have a doctor look at it as soon as you can.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Most cases of sore throat are due to viral infection e.g. as part of flu and cold attack. Bacterial infections on the other hand represent a smaller number of cases. Usually there are other associated symptoms and signs that can point to the possible causative agent.  Viral induced sore throat usually subsides in week with rest and plenty fluid intake.   Being diabetic, and with hypothyroid function , make you more susceptible to recurrent infections as sore throat.  Experts says that a sore throat that lasts for longer than a week is often caused by allergies, or exposure to humidity, smoking, irritation from heating and cooling systems.  Repeated pharyngitis can also happen seasonally or all year long most commonly due to allergies and in this case usually the allergic individual wake up early in the morning with sore throat.   In some cases it is believed to be due to a postnasal discharge.   If you suffer from recurring sore throats, it's also possible that your toothbrush needs to be changed as it may transmit the infection for you after you have recovered from your first attack.   You better try to avoid exposing yourself to any precipitating factor like cold drinks, smoking etc.  A sore throat that does not improve or repeated with a short period of time should be investigated properly. By complete history and proper examination your physician can evaluate the cause of this recurrent sore throat and recommend treatment.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  This sound like a chronic abscess.  Abscess is the body responds to bacteria or to a foreign body as white blood cells migrate to the affected area, attack and destroy them forming pus.  Abscesses may develop in the lip line when the oil (sebaceous) glands become blocked or after minor wounds to the skin.    Recurrent, chronic abscess are formed due to inadequate treatment of acute infection.  An abscess may form on top of any other swelling or mass.  Direct clinical examination is essential for any mass.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear hickory,  Without clinical examination, it is difficult to tell what this lesion could be. Tthe best thing to do is to be examined by the NET specialist as soon as possible.  The lump could be of benign cause, like a cyst or or any lesion in the duct of the submandibular salivary gland.  It might be also mucosal changes associted with one of the systemic disease that you have been diagnosed with.  For example, oral Lichen planus which occurs in people having immunologically mediated disorders. Oral lichen planus (OLP) usually  seen as bilateral white striations, papules, or plaques on the buccal mucosa, tongue, or gingivae.  Oral lichenoid lesions similar to OLP which results from drug reactions in patients receiving one of these drugs:NSAIDs, beta-blockers, sulfonylureas, some ACE inhibitors, etc.  Lichenoid lesions  of unknown cause are known as idiopathic OLP.  In such cases Dermatological examination is necessary.   At same time exclusion of malignant lesions is important. The possible investigations to be requested in your case are X-ray, CT , or MRI and biopsy if needed.  Early malignant or premalignat lesions in the oral cavity can be removed surgically with good outcome.  Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear JenO,  In most of the cases with neck, shoulder and back pain, strain of the back muscles and ligaments, is the primary cause.  This usually results from wrong , sustained positions or following a sudden improper movement.   Muscle spasm alone can cause severe pain which can be of an unidentified cause.  In these cases, self care and avoiding the precipitating cause will lead to a gradual but clear improvement in the pain. Home treatment includes the use of analgesics, hot therapy and physiotherapy. Rest for maximum two days is also beneficial.   If these measures fail to relief the pain or to improve symptoms in 48 hours, or if the pain is associated with numbness , weakness, the pain is more likely to be due to other causes, like:  Herniated disk, in which the intervertebral disc press on his nerves,  Spondylosis which is similar to arthritis but affects the spine etc   You mentioned that the X- ray imagine showed no changes. MRI is of choice in the diagnosis of these cases.  These are conditions that need specific therapy.  My advice is to follow up your doctor and  to consult your him for further investigations like MRI.  Best regards,

title: [no title]
content: Hi soni123, Tongue ulcers can develop for a variety of reasons, for example, dental problems, dietary defieciencies, (B12, folate), autoimmune diseases, etc., including malignancy. author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi PrettynPunk, Please confirm the nature of your finding by direct clinical examination by your physician. It is probably a lymph node it occurs in a lymph node region, however this must be confirmed by your physician. The preauricular lymph nodes are located in front of the ears. They drain the eyelids and conjunctivae, temporal region, pinna. Common causes of enlargement include diseases of the external auditory canal. The submandibular lymph nodes are located along the underside of the jaw on either side. They drain the tongue, submaxillary gland, lips and mouth, conjunctivae. Common causes of enlargement include infections of head, neck, sinuses, ears, eyes, scalp, pharynx. Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders). Infected Lymph nodes however, tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened. Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Upon evaluation your physician may watch and wait for a 3-4 week time period to see if there are any changes or treat with a course of antibiotics if he/she suspects an underlying infection. An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. I would suggest an evaluation by your physician. Sincerely, Theresa Jones, RN

I was too scared to go to the dr's and fet up with it being there, i started messing with it one night, pinchin at it and manipulating it, then finally, it became sore! in the matter of the next 2 days it swelled up and got horribly infected, (note it had NEVER been sore or infected before) it sweeled up to the size of a walnut in the matter of 24 hours, obviously infected now i was worried, so i was gonna head to the dr, and i jumped in the shower and it had sweeled so quickly the skin had become dry and cracked, it popped while i was showering! looked to be a bit of blood in there with some water..I was pretty exicted! AS popping it had flatted it out 100%!!! it was gone, in the matter of the next week, the lil scar from where the skin was cut open was the only noticable thing there. Enter today, 3 months later with no signs of anything...i look in the mirror and i see something again!!!  only this time its about the size of a BB, no bigger, same characteristics, i can lift it off and move it around.  Question obviously is...does this thing seem like a lympnoid? If so, could i manipulate it as i explained? I understand the nodes are close to the skin, but this felt like it was JUST under the skin, like no more then a pimple. Also, if it was a node, and it popped like it did, why would it reoccur exactly the same spot? Wouldnt that node be scared and dead now if you will?   So to summurize, could this be a cancer, if so, why after a year do i hyave no symptoms other then the lump and hpow the heck if it or was a tumor, how does it pop!?   any input will be greatly appreciated!!

content: Hi wrecko, Lymph nodes do not have characteristics of opening and drainage. author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hello Moby Dick,  Most common cause of lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes) is infection. Lymph nodes can also become swollen from inflammatory conditions and cancer. Other causes of enlarged lymph nodes are unusual.  Lymphadenopathy is described as a node larger than 1 cm, but this fluctuates depending on the site where the node is found. Inguinal lymph nodes larger than 1.5 cms. are consider abnormal. In contrast, palpable supraclavicular, iliac, or popliteal nodes of any size, and epitrochlear nodes larger than 5 mm are considered abnormal. Although there is no uniform nodal size at which one should suspect a malignant origin, the presence of one or more lymph nodes larger than 1 cm in diameter calls for further investigation if a definite cause cannot be identified (except inguinal nodes).  Under 30 years of age, lymphadenopathy has an infectious or inflammatory origin in 80% of the cases, while in people over 50 the enlargement is neoplastic 60% of the time.  Supraclavicular lymphadenopathy has more chance to be caused by cancer, in particular, hard feeling ones on the left side.  I think that any adult who recently notice a supraclavicular lymphadenopathy, without specific explanation (e.g., local infection), and feels firm, non-tender, should undergo a biopsy.   Sincerely,  Dr. Alberto de la Guerra.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  There is no replacement for an examination by your doctor, please get an appointment if its still an issue.  Best regards.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  You didn't state your age but it seems from your post that you are probably young.   Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Lymph nodes harboring malignant disease tend to be firm, non-tender, matted (ie, stuck to each other), fixed (ie, not freely mobile but rather stuck down to underlying tissue), and increase in size over time.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  In primary care settings, patients 40 years of age and older with unexplained lymphadenopathy have about a 4 percent risk of cancer versus a 0.4 percent risk in patients younger than age 40.[1]  I am in no position to comment on the white bumps especially that the doctor did not find them on examination. I hope you are feeling better by now and that you are in good health.  Best regards.  References: ========== 1. Fijten GH, Blijham GH. Unexplained lymphadenopathy in family practice. An evaluation of the probability of malignant causes and the effectiveness of physicians' workup. J Fam Pract 1988;27: 373-6.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).  The submental lymph node is located just below the chin. It drains the lower lip, floor of mouth, teeth, submental salivary gland, tip of tongue, skin of cheek. Common causes of enlargement include mononucleosis syndromes, Epstein-Barr virus, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, dental pathology such as periodontitis.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that epitrochlear nodes larger than 0.5 cm or inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal [1,2].  An increase in nodal size on serial examinations is significant. Hence nodes that continue to grow in size are important and those that regress in size tend to be more reassuring.  References: ========== 1. Libman H. Generalized lymphadenopathy. J Gen Intern Med 1987;2:48-58. 2. Morland B. Lymphadenopathy. Arch Dis Child 1995; 73:476-9.

title: Swollen Glands, reoccuring sore throats, pain swallowing.
content: I'm a 26 year old Male, who doesn't smoke and rarely drinks. About 6 months ago I noticed a small, 1/2 inch lump on the right side of my neck. my doctor took a look at it and didn't seem concerned. said it was just a lymph node. I had bronchitis at the time.   The bronchitis cleared up in April and I was okay for a while. Then in May I came down with strep. Treated that and it went away. A little over a month ago I went in again with a sore throat, strep came back negative, but doctor said I had an ear in fection in both ears. put me on amoxicillin. By the end of my course, the ear infection was gone, but I had a nasty sore throat. Went back and was diagnosed with Strep. 3 days after finishing the amoxicillin. I was put on Z-pac and a nasal spray for PND. Cleard up for a couple of days. But I've been feeling run down ever since. And I've had this odd discomfort on the right side of my throat near my thyroid. There was minor discomfort swallowing but it seemed to go away after the strep.  Last week I've had some bad pain on the right side of my neck. Made turning to the right a bit painful. I noticed a smal (1/2 inch) bump near my thyroid, right above the collar bone. Again, it's not huge, but it does feel like a lymph node. While the pain in my neck is mostly gone, that wierd feeling is still there.   Today, I feel like i'm coming down with the flu. Achy, dizzy and have the beginnings of a sore throat. I'm sick (haha) of going to the doctor's. But this is getting rediculous. I hang out a lot with friends who have young children (5 & 2), but it just seems odd that my immune system is this lame at taking care of anything they might have. Neither of them seem sick, and I've been hanging out with them for the last 2 years.   Should I be concerned about the frequency I'm getting sick, or should I chock it up to hanging around children coupled with a "I shoudl really get around to having my wisdom teeth out"? Or is it something more serious?  And while we're on the subject, No, I don't seem to be running a fever, having night sweats, and sadly, there's no apparent weight loss.

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I hope you are feeling better by now. It's normal to have repeated throat infections from time to time. However, you should inform your doctor as he would be the person that can best assess your case.   I am sure if s/he suspects that there is anything wrong with your immune system they would have asked for further investigation.  Regarding your lymph node question: Abnormal lymph node enlargement tends to commonly result from infection / immune response, cancer and less commonly due to infiltration of macrophages filled with metabolite deposits (eg, storage disorders).   Infected Lymph nodes tend to be firm, tender, enlarged and warm. Inflammation can spread to the overlying skin, causing it to appear reddened.  Sometimes, following infection lymph nodes occasionally remain permanently enlarged, though they should be non-tender, small (less the 1 cm), have a rubbery consistency and none of the characteristics described for malignancy or for infection. These are also known as 'Shotty Lymph nodes'.  Best regards.

Again I'm told everything is ok. Now....I noticed a lump in my lymph node behind my jaw bone under my ear lobe. I have read a lot of online reports about lumps in glands and swollen glands. These all seem small compaired to mine. I can "grab" mine and it feels a little smaller than a golf ball. Its shaped like an egg. It feels hard but not rock hard. author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hi Mochazzz,  Sorry I have not been able to respond earlier. Even though the only way to be sure of the nature of your tumor is to have it in front and examine it properly, I will try to help you based just on the information I have. Behind the jaw bone (retromandibular) and under the earlobe there are many structures (skin, bone, nerves, lymph nodes, the parotid salivary gland, etc). A bump can develop from any of those structures, and could be of benign or malignant nature. From your description of the tumor, it appears to me it could be either an enlarged lymph node or a parotid salivary gland tumor.  As you may have read online, the most common cause of bumps or swollen lymph nodes in the neck are infections. But, when an adult presents a lateral neck mass, in the absence of obvious signs of infection, it is deemed to be cancer until proved otherwise (75% of lateral neck masses in adults over 40 yo are malignant). However, no symptom or complex of symptoms is strongly correlated with cancer.  About your question on how big is swollen, cervical lymph nodes larger than 1 cm. should be considered abnormal. Therefore, a node a little smaller than a golf ball is like 4 cms in diameter, and calls for further investigation. Additionally, it is well documented that solid organ transplantation with its inherent immunosuppression is complicated by an increased incidence of malignancy, particularly cancers of the lymph nodes (lymphomas); and radiotherapy increases cancer risk. As well, retromandibular lymph nodes can directly mirror squamous cell carcinomas of the pharynx, larynx, tonsils, tongue, and tumors of the parotid gland.  Almost 80% of all salivary gland tumors occur in the parotid, and 75% of them are benign. The most common type is the benign pleomorphic adenoma, usually a slow-growing, painless lump at the back of the jaw, just below the earlobe. These tumors are more frequent in people exposed to radiation. Besides, if someone has had radiation treatment to the head and neck area for other medical reasons, the risk of salivary gland cancer increases.  My intention is not to scare you, but due to your past medical history of total lymph irradiation, immunosuppressive treatment, and squamous cell carcinoma arising in two different sites, I strongly encourage you to seek for medical attention.  Sincerely,  Dr Torax.

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi dms, Unfortunately, chemotherapy/radiation  may produce severe mucositis. My question for you, is your husband being treated for this condition? There are medications used as numbing agents, for example, (maalox, benadryl, lidocaine) used as a swish and swallow. There has been approval by the FDA (Food and Drug Administration) of a medication, palifermin, which is used in treatment of severe oral mucositis. I would suggest inquiring about treatment for his condition. Treatment reduces the severity and duration of the condition. Best wishes to you both  Sincerely, Rntdj

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi niceboy_017, Lymph nodes commonly enlarge do to infection from bacteria or virus states and may not return to their pre-infectious size after an infection subsides. Lymph nodes that continue to enlarge despite treatment are more disconcerting. Infections of the mouth/throat may cause these nodes to enlarge. Enlargement of these nodes may also be associated with systemic disorders, for example, lymphoma, autoimmune disorders, HIV, etc. Other presenting symptoms are usually apparent. If you are experiencing drenching night sweats, my suggestion for you is inquire with your physician about a CT scan. My second suggestion would be, if you have been sexually active, involved in drug use, etc., that you also inquire about a HIV test. Sincerely, Rntdj

title: Squamous Cell Carcinoma | Tonsil Primary
content: (this is a copy of the last post from my Lymphoma thread, which I am "moving" to this category from Lymphoma and also the Cancer of Unknown Primary)  I know a positive attitude is essential in every study I read and everyone I talk to so maybe the Dr's telling me 50 to 70% survival chance are using inflated odds to improve the odds?  Here's why I am concerned:  I've read that people under 40, in no other risk groups who get this (ie: "me"), usually have a much more agressive neoplasm. This is what I've heard from a couple of sources...So, maybe the Dr with the 70% odds he's using, for his outlook; has demographics of generally older patients who smoke, etc who don't have such an agressive version.  4 ENT's & 1 Oncological Surgeon have said 50-50 chance of 5 year survival.  There's tremendous consistency in that number...It's also a "safe" bet, meaning whatever happends, they are right..   But, maybe there's some code out there that say's "if the patient has less than 50% chance, tell them 50-50 just to keep them sane..", or maybe that's what they say when they don't really know.  That is the bottom line after all. They DON'T really know. No one does, and that's the problem with statistics.  I have this mental block about all the 50-50 projections, I feel like I would be measurably more resolved if they would have all said 55 or 60% chance...Crazy huh?  But, again, that's what following statistics is..."CRAZY". None of us is a statistic.  SO...I've decided.  I'm 36 DAMNIT! I'm a healthy male (other than the whole "cancer thing"  )  I'm not going to fall into the crowd on the failing side of the 50%.   I've got way too much life left in me and too much to live for.  Just do me a favor everyone, on those days in the future when I forget this, please give me a gentle reminder    Now for my plan:  1) Radical Tonsilectomy  & Modified Radical Neck Dissection  next week 5 hour surgery! (Please keep me in your prayers that day)   Top ENT Surgeon @ Stanford  2) 2 weeks of recovery at our resort my partner and I own on the North Coast. We'll work on getting computers setup, phones forwarded, systems in place, people trained, hired etc for our absense.  3) Right after our busy July 4th weekend, we'll leave for So Cal where we have a home and all our familes and lots of friends live, to start Radiation/Chemo, maybe using one of two new drugs in combination, Motexafin Gadolinium &/or Proxinium, and possibly Erbitux. This will likely be a six week cycle. This will be supervised by the Stanford team and administered by a great local oncologist (the 70% guy!!). Friends and family will help my parter and I run our resort remotely (as much as possible), and help me with trips to radiation and chemo, and meals, chores, etc. Every weekend or two, my parter (me too when I'm feeling up to it), will run up there and check things out in person (9 hour drive each way!  ) Returning to be back in time for the next radiation treatment. Family will stay at the place occassionally to check on the employees, releave people, etc.  The radiation I plan to use is the new TomoTherapy. I've read a ton about it. It's not available up North, and my charts are being reviewed by the chief of radiology at one of the installations now. He said it is brand new and they plan to use it on a lot of H&N cancers.  Okay, so that's the plan. There's a chance they won't get it all on surgery. There's a chance they won't get it all with radiation/chemo, and there's an ugly chance it will return with a vengence! But, I'll be ready..!!  I have several other things up my sleeve, like Gendicine, Avenox and more ideas.  Plus, I'm radically changing my diet to be "cancer resistent".  I've gone 8 days now with ZERO coffee or caffeine! (Unbelieveable I was a total espresso junkie 2 weeks ago)  I am going to be more active, exercise and be overall healthy.  Plus, everyday I am going to visualize my body eating up all the cancer cells (my Dr (from Stanford!!) actually suggested this!!!!)    That's the plan...! Help me stick with it!  I feel so connected to all of you. Thank you for all the inspiration, prayers and good wishes.  Hopefully, my surgery will go smooth, and they will find good results in the biopsies (ie: Little tissue involvement, no spreading, clean small margins, and no other nodes.)  Sorry for the LONG post
posted_time: Post  by Michaelii » Sat Jun 18, 2005 11:05 am

author: Kim C, RN  Nurse Posts: 39 Joined: Fri Jun 17, 2005 7:36 pm Location: New Orleans, Louisiana
title: [no title]
content: Don't apologize for the long post, you have good reason for it!   If you have any questions about what your hospital stay might be like, please feel free to ask. I've worked Surgical ICU for 7 years and will be happy to answer whatever I can. Also, so that you are prepared, it might be a good idea to visit the unit that you'll be going to after your surgery BEFORE the surgery. Your surgeon should be able to tell you where you'll be going. Ask the nurses what to expect, and how the routine of the unit works. Ask about any equipment you'll be seeing when you wake up, so that you're not startled by anything. I've found that this has helped many patients have less anxiety, and it also gives them a familiar face to see when they arrive from surgery.   You are in my thoughts and prayers for a good outcome to your surgery and a speedy recovery. Get online as soon as you can after surgery so you can update us, and so we can "assist" you in maintaining that positive attitude!   (((hugs)))
posted_time: Post  by Kim C, RN » Sat Jun 18, 2005 6:02 pm

author: Kim C, RN  Nurse Posts: 39 Joined: Fri Jun 17, 2005 7:36 pm Location: New Orleans, Louisiana
title: [no title]
content: Unfortunately your friend is right about the dry mouth!! If I had a dollar for every time a patient complained of that I'd be a wealthy woman!  Some anesthesia has the side effect of dry mouth. Believe it or not, some surgical patients can be overloaded with fluid and yet be terribly thirsty! One way to deal with that is the lip balm. Another is to ask for mouth swabs... dip them in ice water and swab your mouth with them. I'm not sure if this will be an option for you right away due to the type of surgical procedure you'll be having, but again, your nurses should tell you and/or your partner what is permissible.   A few more pointers while I'm thinking of them:  Clarify everything with your surgeon. Ask questions about the immediate post-op period. What unit will you be in right after surgery? Will you be on a ventilator (breathing machine) for any length of time? (This may be necessary, for a short time,  to protect your airway from the swelling that can occur after such a long surgery in the throat/neck area. You will want to know this ahead of time so that you are not scared when you "wake up" with a breathing tube in.)  DO NOT try to be a hero and "deal with" any pain. Ask for, and take, pain medicine. It helps you rest better, and your body needs this to recover! Also, people in pain tend to not want to move around, and this can also lead to complications like pneumonia and blood clots.  Limit your visitors in the beginning. I understand that people love you and want to come see you to cheer you up and keep you company. The usual issue I've found in this scenario is that the patient feels obligated to entertain the visitors and winds up worn out, in pain, and generally feeling like crap. SO, ask anyone outside your immediate circle to save their well-wishes for when you're feeling up to company. And DON'T feel guilty about it.  Anyone, ANYONE, who enters your room is to thoroughly wash their hands, or use an alcohol-based hand sanitizer, before they touch you, your bed, your call-light, anything. NO EXCEPTIONS. NONE. I cannot stress this enough. Wash your hands frequently as well, especially if you have a room mate. And for God's sake don't walk around bare foot!!    Okay, I've written a novella here... so I'll climb down off the soap box. Again, if you have any questions, please feel free to ask.   P.S. What date is your surgery again??

author: Michaelii  Guest Posts: 42 Joined: Fri Apr 22, 2005 12:51 am Location: California
title: Treatment Plan ...Advise needed
content: I have been DX as Stage IV, T1N2, or T2N2.  I have now seen or spoken to 26 Drs.  About half of them ENT/Surgeons. The other half are made up of Radiation Oncologists and Chemo. Onocologists.  I am more confused than ever.  Several of the Oncologists STRONGLY recommend against surgery as the 1st line in my case, stateing that the best chance I have is from a combination Taxol/Carbo and Erbitux (which according to recent report is showing "statistically significant improvements" in H&N SCC.)  The problem, I'm told, is that when I have the surgery first, the blood vessels and scar tissues damages make it impossible for the medicines to reach the areas of need.  My surgeon calls them "neophites", and say's that if I don't have the surgery I will die, and even if I do, there is a 30-50% chance that I'll make it to the 5 year mark anyway.  He say's that since I am under 40 years old and don't have risk factors, that in his experience, the neoplasm is always MORE AGRESSIVE, to justify surgery NOW.  Is the concern over the surgery scars and blood vessel damage justified?  The surgeon plans a Right Side, Modified Radical Neck Dissection and a Radical Tonsilectomy.  I am so confused and don't know what to do!?!?!  I feel like I NEED to get started NOW with whatever course I'm taking, but of course I want to do what's best.  Can anyone help me understand?
posted_time: Post  by Michaelii » Sat Jun 25, 2005 9:50 am

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hi there, I would like to add that the dry mouth experienced in patients treated for head and neck cancer is most troublesome in pateints exposed to radiation therapy as this may permanently damage the mucous secreting epithelium in the oropharynx.  As regards the optimum therapy for your case I certainly do not want to be the doctor number 27 on your list. There are a lot of confusing opinions and that is why the National Cancer Institute publishes its recommended guidelines. These are regularly updated. I would also recommend that you refer to a surgical oncologist that specializes in oropharyngeal cancers.  NCI PDQ link! There is also a link to a patient version at the top of the page.

title: Weird bumps/fins on tongue
content: I hope this is the right forum..  Ok, about 4 days ago, I noticed my tongue feeling weird, constant tingling, a little numbness, and a little burning. I felt some pain when I would lift my tongue up all the way. I had also noticed some soreness on the underside of my tongue. And it seemed when I woke up in the morning, my tongue was swollen (I don't know if this is common or not, it hasn't been for me). Then I looked in the mirror to see what was going on, and on the underside of my tongue, I noticed some bumps and I think some of those bumps became a little um...tentacle looking, not too long, but it was like a flappy fin, but just as small as the bumps though. Now, 2 days later, I notice the same bumps and fins developing on the side of my tongue near my wisdom teeth, and all along the side of my tongue to the very tip of my tongue (its as if they're developing points on my tongue, picture the points on an octagon, thats how its starting to form), from the back, they are bigger, and get smaller as it goes toward the front. All of these bumps, on the side and back are reddish in color. I believe I had some growing on the other side of my tongue also, but for some reason, it went back to normal. My throat felt a little funny too, kind of sore, I actually remember this being the first symptom, my throat was really sore before the problems with my tongue started. Also, I understand that white bumps on the very back of the tongue is normal, right? Well, I have some big red ones, is that normal? And what kind of doctor would be in the best position to treat me?

author: Theresa Jones, RN  Nurse Posts: 2365 Joined: Tue Sep 28, 2004 10:21 am
title: [no title]
content: Hi Yung_Trae53, Lymph nodes commonly enlarge due to an infection because they are the bodies filtering system for bacteria. They may not return to their preinfectious size. However, you may want to have the areas evaluated by your physician to assure this is the causative factor and that it is not related to any other anomalies. Sincerely, Rntdj

content: Hi Yung_Trae53, Generally speaking lymph nodes that are hard and fixed are much more concerning than the one's that are mobile (which usually indicate an infection etc.) Have a physician evaluate the areas to alleviate your concerns. Sincerely, Rntdj

author: mkw222  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Wed May 04, 2005 12:10 am Location: Albany, Ga
title: UPDATE!!!
content: Hey! The pain got worse and it spread to the right side of my chest, under my right arm, and all the way around to my back. What's wierd is that it didn't hurt all the time. Most of the time it would start when I laid down. This went on for a couple of days and by Saturday night I was hurting so bad that I had no choice but to go to the emergency room. Of course, they ended up admitting me and doing surgery. I had many many many Gall Stones!!! On the sonogram it was really bad. My gall bladder was full of stones. And now I am home from the hospital and am in pain from the surgery and from the urinary tract infection I got at the hospital. Yeah, sucks huh? Anyway, I am relieved that it was something that could be fixed. Why do we even have gall bladders anyway? We can live with them or without them.

author: toni  Guest Posts: 2 Joined: Sun Dec 26, 2004 11:37 am Location: california
title: losing voice, sore throat, and lump
content: Right up front - I smoke. I have smoked for 34 years.  Over the past year, or so, I have developed an "on again, off again" sore throat. The soreness is isolated to the right side only. Sometimes, it feels as if I am trying to swallow a small lump, other times it feels as if there is something very small stuck inside, and other times I feel nothing at all.  I have a cough. Sometimes it is clearly a "smoker's cough", but other times it is a "tickling" cough. When it's the "tickling cough", I have no control over it. The coughing, more often than not, leads to a bout of sneezing. The "tickle" that I'm trying to cough away will make me sneeze. Over and over until the coughing subsides. Cough-sneeze-cough-sneeze, etc..  Since this all started, I also began to lose my voice. It's gradually become worse. At this point in time, it's become so bad that I cannot sing anymore at all. If I try to sing, my voice will simply disappear even though I'm trying very hard to push out sound. If sound does manage to sneak out, it will change pitch uncontrollably and the "noise" will come and go, come and go (i.e., noise-silence-noise-silence). Also, if I talk for any length of time - even sometimes right from the onset of speech - my voice will quickly turn hoarse and then start breaking up.  Could my voice/sore throat/coughing problems be completely related to irritation of the throat caused by smoking? Or do these symptoms sound as if it might be something a bit more serious?  Thank you very much.

title: Submandibular lump
content: About a week ago I noticed a lump in my neck.  The lump is submandibular, directly midline, just where my chin and my neck meet.  The lump is fixed, hard, and tender, though not painful.  It doesn't seem to have any invovlment with my throat and I've had no hoarsness or recent URI's.  I have not noticed any enlargement of any lymph nodes and I have been without fever.  I have, however, been very fatigued lately.  I have not had any dramatic weight loss.  I saw a physician today and because they were very busy I felt as if I was not assessed as I should have been.  This physician noticed a blemish on my chin that's small and scabbed over.  She did not do a complete H&P, collect any labs, nor did she enquire about s/s I might have.  She said that this lump was likely an enlarged lymph node r/t my pimple.  I explained that I have had the lump days before the pimple appeared.  She left and came back and wrote me a prescription for an antibiotic.  She said that I should come back in two weeks after taking the antibiotic and if the lump has not gone away.  My question is whether or not it's likely that a blemish could be the result of this lump in my neck and should I continue with the antibiotic as she prescirbed and follow up afterwards or should I see another physician?

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Hello, Tenderness is one sign favouring inflammation to cancer as a cause of your lymph node enlargement. How large is your lymph node. Depending on your examination if the index of suspicion for malignancy is not high the standard procedure would be to prescribe an antibiotic and check after 2 weeks. Take into consideration that the most common cause of lymph node enlargement is infection.  It could be related to the scab you are describing or to a hidden septic focus. Either way I would agree with your doctors decision.  Best regards,

title: RT or not to RT?
content: IS radiation theraphy (RT) absolutely required after a neck dissection where the tumor was classed as TxN1M0?  What are my risks if I do not take RT but continue with checkups, diet, exercise?

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: What was the pathological type of tumor involved? Was the origin of the tumor determined or were you diagnosed as having an occult malignancy with spread in the lymph nodes of the neck?
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Aug 11, 2004 5:42 am

author: jteasley  Guest Posts: 3 Joined: Mon Aug 09, 2004 12:52 pm Location: Winston-Salem
title: RT or Not
content: The information below is taken directly from the Pathologic report:  Sublingual tonsils free of neoplasm Biopsy of left tongue base -- mild to moderate squamous dysplasia Soft tissue from left neck -- Invasive poorly to moderately differentiated squamous cell carcinoma, probably representing a nodal metastasis (see comment below), incidental, adjacent lymph nodes free of neoplasm Nasopharnx free of neoplasm Tonsil, left paletine tonsil-- free of neoplasm, mild active cryptitis  Comment: The left neck mass is histologically consistent with a nodal metastasis or a primary in a branchial cleft cyst. The cystic neoplasm is surrounded by a lamina of lymphoid tissue which occasionally contains germinal centers, but no lymph nodesinuses are observed. Nevertheless, syudies have demostrated that most cases resembling squamous cell carcinoma arising in a branchial cleft cyst turn out to be nodal metastasis with subsequent demonstration of another primary source.  I hope I have provided the correct info. Thanks for your reply.  Here are a few words from an onocologist I am seeeing:  "I did speak to the pathologist. Apparently the pathology was not labeled properly and so nodal counts which are usually done on neck dissections were not done. One node was involved with cancer and there was no extracapsular spread. The size was 3.5 x 5.0 cm on the CT scan which means it is a stage N2a. Your base of tongue biopsy also shows dysplasia which is suggestive  of an underlying malignancy in the base of tongue."

author: Dr. Tamer Fouad  Medical Doctor Posts: 2563 Joined: Thu Jan 02, 2003 6:19 pm Gender: Male
title: [no title]
content: Its possible that the associated tongue dysplasia is the culprit, hiding behind it the source. As for whether you should receive radiotherapy or not, it all depends on the extent of neck dissection that you have undergone. It seems that in your case unfortunately the lymph node count was not performed. This puts you at risk of inadequate therapy. I personally think that combined surgery and radiation therapy is mandatory in your case. Radiation fields may involve the base of the tongue as well. Please speak with your radiotherapist about the procedure and possible complications.   Best regards,
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Tamer Fouad » Wed Aug 11, 2004 2:28 pm

author: Dr. Brim M.  Medical Doctor Posts: 16 Joined: Thu Dec 23, 2004 2:32 am Location: Birmingham, AL
title: [no title]
content: Usually post-operative radiotherapy after a neck dissection is offered for more than one lymph node involved or if there are positive surgical margins or spread beyond the capsule of the lymph node (extracapsular extension).   However, you mentioned Tx (unknown primary tumor).  Even in the absense of the above risk factors, most radiation oncologists would offer radiotherapy for an unknown primary cancer.  This would include all mucosal areas and both sides of the neck.  With fancier radiotherapy techniques (IMRT), you might just get the one side of the neck treated.    Did you have a PET scan to look for a primary tumor?
posted_time: Post  by Dr. Brim M. » Thu Dec 23, 2004 3:24 am

title: Time interval between RT and bone scan?
content: Hello, I am writing this on behalf of a relative who lives in Europe. 62 year old female, history of moderate smoking and alcohol use Otherwise in good health DIAGNOSIS: Squamous cell carcinoma of oral cavity May 2004 Modest surgical treatment June 2004 Radiation treatment ended 24 Sept 2004 MRI (first) 10.13.04 MRI (second) 11.17.04  She still is in extreme discomfort following the radiation therapy. Her surgeon now wants to remove her mandible, which she is not willing to do. They are considering coming to the US to seek out some other treatment. From what I have gathered from other sources, a bone scan should be performed to see if the cancerhas metasticized to other areas, however I have also heard that there should be some recovery period between the radiation therapy and the bone scan. Does the radiation-induced damage interfere with the interpretation of the bone scan?   Any advice is greatly appreciated!  Thank you

author: CED  Guest Posts: 6 Joined: Sat Jun 14, 2003 10:22 pm Location: Chicago Suburbs
title: [no title]
content: Would hopefully like to clarify a few parameters first... When you say modest surgical intervention, was there just soft tissue or both soft and bone removed?? Was there an improvement seen with the 1st MRI to the second along with improvement in healing of surgerized area??  Having discomfort still since 24th of September would not be out of the ordinary considering the treatment; again, the extensiveness of the surgical treatment, biopsy results are important..  What concern me is that from your statement, the Surgeon wants to remove the mandible ---> my assumption is that he sees something from post-op tests and physical examination....  Let me say here and now that with the magnitude of the Squamous Cell Carcinoma diagnosis, the seriousness and/or aggressiveness of proposed treatment requires anyone in this situation(even a lesser one) to get a 2nd opinion; any good Doctor with anyone's health in mind should always tell a patient to get a 2nd opinion especially given this situation...  Yes, the radiation treatment could create a slower healing process and therefore this should be taken in consideration when doing a bone scan ===> again allot depends on the initial invasive procedure.... If coming to the US is an option for a second opinion and viable, then by all means do so...

title: [no title]
content: Dear CED, Thank you so much for replying to my message.  Sorry for the vague details about the surgical intervention. I'm relying on an engineer to translate the medical document. Also it seems that some of the  eastern European medical systems provide minimal information to the family and patient regarding their condition.   In regard to the intial surgery, cancerous lesions were removed from the right side of the tongue in May. So only soft tissue removed. Following surgery there was a disagreement between the surgeon and the radiologist whether radiotherapy should be started. They decided not have radiotherapy and check every two weeks. (looking back this seems like a bad choice).  During one of these check-ups two months later, a biopsy indicated more cancer in the tongue and radiotherapy started the next day. They did *not* do a pre-therapy MRI, nor investigate problems with her teeth. Radiotherapy, totaling 70 Gy (not sure if this unit is correct) proceeded 5 days per week for 35 days. The fact that they started radiotherapy the following day after being told they were booked solid indicates that they were deeply concerned.  Based on two MRIs, 3 and 7 weeks following the radiotherapy, removal of the manidibula was suggested.  I am trying to get the MRIs reviewed within my network of colleagues but it is a pretty slow process as I am three or four people removed from the radiologist.  She is scheduled to visit the surgeon today but I think they are going to put off this drastic surgery until she can be re-evaluated at a cancer center in the US. We are looking into MD Anderson, Sloan-Kettering and the University of Michigan.  What you say about the discomfort following radiotherapy jibes with what I've heard from other sources. Apparantly there was almost no information given to her addressing  these issues (she was told to take an aspirin).   Again, thank you for responding.

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Please help
content: Dear Worried,  Thank you very much for the update.  From what you mentioned, it looks that your dad was worked up very well to rule out any local malignancy in the neck that could be pressing on the veins of his neck cauing this or any mass in the chest as well that could be pressing on the big veins of his heart as well. Does your dad have swelling anywhere else like his feet although this is going to be hard to tell as he is getting hydrochlorothiazide for his high blood pressure which is a diuretic so he might have swelling in the feet but since he takes a diuretic it could not be apparent.  i am not sure how bad is your dad's swelling and where is it localized to or is it more prominent in some parts of the head (like the eyes for instance) more than others?  This is a situation where i can only tell you a few thoughts that you might want to consider taking to your doctors if you think they sound reasonable enough as obviosuly your dad has been taken care of very well so far, as the things that you mentioned were done for him were first on my list as regards to his age and symptoms.  You have not mentioned anything about your father's smoking history but he now has asthma. i am not sure whether he has emphysema or not as well (if he was a smoker a long time ago). Sometimes, if a patient has emphysema, he will develop mild swelling of neck and eyes as well. Will fell a headache and has chronic fatigue, reason being that the patient has low oxygen in the blood and sometimes high carbon dioxide as well which give rise to these symptoms. So my suggestion is to have your dad have an echocardiogram (an ultrasound of the heart) to see if your dad has high pulmonary artery pressures in addition to any other abnormality that could be there and affecting the venous flow to the heart. Also, to have your dad have a pulmonary function test done to see his overall lung functions. If his pulmonary artery pressures are high and his lungs functions are normal or not severe enough to justify high pulmonary artery pressures then he should have a sleeping study to rule out sleep apnea (which can give all these symptoms as well especially the chronic fatigue).  Also, just in case your father has not had any blood work done, i suggest that he has a liver function panel, kidney function tests and urine analysis to see if this swelling is related to any dysfunction of these organs.  i am not sure whether the mri and/or the ct scans were done with contrast or without contrast but if they were done without contrast, i think the best next step is to repeat them with iv contrast injection as it allows better visualization of the vascular system.  Thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.   Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.

title: Recurrent orbital hemangioma
content: I have a 3yr male child first seen by me 9 months back with lt. eye proptosis. CT revealed 1*1 cm.retro bulber lesion with marked cantrast enhancement involving lat. rectus. Lat. orbitotomy excision of tumor was done. Histopath revealed features of haemangioma. 15 days post surgery local triamcenelone 10 mg 3 injections 4wks. appart given. Now pt presented with recurrent orbital mass. CT shows huge catrast enhancing mass involing entire lat. rectus medialy displacing opic nerve also.  I am looking for comments and suggestions regarding management.  Dr Deepak Agrawal e mail:  dr_deepakagrawal@rediffmail.com
posted_time: Post  by Guest » Sun Feb 23, 2003 11:03 am

author: Dr. Yasser Mokhtar  Medical Doctor Posts: 1387 Joined: Sun Dec 29, 2002 1:24 pm
title: Re: Recurrent orbital hemangioma
content: Dear Dr. Agrawal,  Thank you very much for using our website.  Not being an ophthalmologist or a pediatrician, i searched the electronic litterature and found some information about orbital hemangiomas in children.  Because the majority of hemangiomas require no intervention, the decision to treat should be based on location and depth of the lesion, age of the patient, and likelihood of complication.   Indications for intervention in cases of orbital hemangiomas include: 1. Amblyopia. 2. Compressive optic neuropathy. 3. Proptosis with globe exposure.   Treatment modalities include  1. Intralesional corticosteroid injection. 2. Systemic corticosteroids. 3. Radiotherapy. 4. Laser therapy. 5. Systemic interferon. 6. Surgery. Surgery should be considered for localized, noninfiltrative lesions, or for those that fail to respond to corticosteroids 7. Interferon. 8. Embolization can be used to treat cutaneous hemangiomas that have not responded to medical therapy.  This is a summary of what i found.  Once more, thank you very much for using our website http://doctorslounge.com and i hope that this information helped.  Yasser Mokhtar, M.D.
